quotes.quote: Those we love can but walk down to the pier with us - the voyage we must make alone.
Some people wait so long for their ship to come in, their pier collapses.
A life spent at the edge of the pier is a life full of regret, a life full of fear.

It blows a snowing gale in the winter of the year; The boats are on the sea and the crews are on the pier. The needle of the vane, it is veering to and fro, A flash of sun is on the veering of the vane. Autumn leaves and rain, The passion of the gale.
In my mind, in here, It's like standing too close to the edge on pier where waves spit on toes and scream into ears their wails and woes and deepest fears.
That ruined pier... it says a thousand things.
Piers are good places for pondering the eternal enigmas of the universe.
An amusement pier juts out into the sea, a place where strangers meet.
Old Nick, the sea captain, was a rough, tough, jolly sort of fellow. He loved the life of the sea, and he loved to hang out down by the pier where the men dressed as ladies...
Why don't you take a long walk / Off a short pier / You'll just keep messing with my head
Walking on to a pier was to be transported ever closer to raw, untamed nature, heightening both the sense of admiration of nature and the accomplishment of the individual making the visit.
The pier, as a platform from which to view the horizon, allowed people to reflect on themselves, other places and other times.
The pier was remarkable in seeming to enable people to journey a little closer to the unobtainable.
Despite their popular association with fun and frivolity, the function of piers a both an amusement centre and landing stage.
Piers were also erected in the area for naval and military purposes.
The piers that remain continue to be the focal point of their towns and are, on the whole, much cherished.
The pier was also a magnet for bathing, provide a platform from which to fish, and was a promenade.
A carousel, roller coaster, and huge ballroom were grafted onto the main pier.
Because it's wharves were no longer in major competition for transport duties, the pleasure pier became the main seaside commodity.
The natural appeal of the ocean drew a number of tourists that frequented the pier despite its modest design.
The notion of a pier made solely for the purpose of walking above the water had a tremendous appeal to people, possibly as a metaphor for humanity conquering the sea.
Over the years, the pier has been subject to storms and fires and has been constructed and reconstructed.

Simple fishing pier. No souvenir shops for the tourists or fancy restaurants, this early pier attracted those who wanted their catch-of-the-day to feed the family or to be a snapshot to show the folks back home how they caught the big one.
The new pier, with its restaurant, bar, and bandstand, was built not for serious trade and commerce but solely for holiday treats and pleasures.
If you believe that this life is all there is and there is no greater power than man, you must walk to the end of this pier at sunset.
The constant about this pier is that it has always made me and mine happy when we walked, sat, or lay on it in the sunlight or moonlight.
A pier is a disappointed bridge; yet stare at it for long enough and you can dream it to the other side of the Channel.
The owners of these piers have changed, and the piers themselves have seen more interesting sights than most two-by-fours throughout the world.
Standing on this old pier is a good way for me to reflect.
